@graph.name: Section 4.2: Creating lightweight FAIR Digital Objects with RO-Crate

@graph.name: Section 5.3: Incrementally building FAIR Digital Objects with Specimen Data Refinery workflows
RQ1
@graph.description: Research Question 1, aims for FAIR Digital Objects on the Web
@graph.text: Can the promising FDO concept be realised using existing Web technology, taking into account the lessons learnt from the early Semantic Web developments and more recent Linked Data practices?

@graph.name: RQ2
@graph.description: Research Question 2, aims for FAIR Research Objects
@graph.text: Can a more pragmatic use of Linked Data practices better implement Research Objects for a wider developer audience, by using familiar Web technologies and give lightweight recommendations?

@graph.name: RQ3
@graph.description: Research Question 3, ims for FAIR Computational Workflows
@graph.text: Can a FAIR Digital Object approach for computational workflows unify machine-readable descriptions of Research Software, data and provenance, which can be consistently implemented by developers of different workflow management systems?

@graph.creditText: Stian Soiland-Reyes, et al. (2022): Packaging research artefacts with RO-Crate. Data Science 5(2)
@graph.name: Section 4.1: Packaging research artefacts with RO-Crate
Section 4.3: Formalizing RO-Crate in First Order Logic

@graph.creditText: Alex Hardisty, et al. (2022): The Specimen Data Refinery: A canonical workflow framework and FAIR Digital Object approach to speeding up digital mobilisation of natural history collections. Data Intelligence 4(2)
@graph.name: Section 5.2: The Specimen Data Refinery: A canonical workflow framework and FAIR Digital Object approach to speeding up digital mobilisation of natural history collections

@graph.creditText: Stian Soiland-Reyes, et al. (2022): Updating Linked Data practices for FAIR Digital Object principles. Research Ideas and Outcomes 8:e94501
@graph.name: Section 3.2: Updating Linked Data practices for FAIR Digital Object principles

@graph.description: In this chapter, we discuss the related work with respect to FAIR Digital Objects and Linked Data. We do so by looking through the lens of development of these technologies over time, including future directions.
@graph.name: Chapter 2: Background

@graph.creditText: Stian Soiland-Reyes, et al. (2024): Evaluating FAIR Digital Object and Linked Data as distributed object systems. PeerJ Computer Science 10:e1781
@graph.name: Section 3.1: Evaluating FAIR Digital Object and Linked Data as distributed object systems
Comparison tables for Evaluating FAIR Digital Object and Linked Data (RO-Crate)

@graph.description: To investigate RQ1 this chapter evaluates both Linked Data and FAIR Digital Object (FDO) as ways to realize the FAIR principles. Section 3.1 compares the two approaches as global distributed object systems, and discusses what lessons can be learnt across the communities, taking into consideration the history covered by section 2.       Section 3.2 proposes how the FDO principles can be achieved using Linked Data standards, which is explored further in the following chapters.
@graph.name: Chapter 3: FAIR Digital Objects and Linked Data

@graph.description: This chapter introduces RO-Crate, a pragmatic method of packaging data alongside structured metadata that is inline with the FAIR principles. This has been implemented to investigate RQ2. Section 4.1 describes the RO-Crate purpose, community effort and tooling and demonstrates how RO-Crate has been applied. Section 4.2 shows how RO-Crate can be used to achieve the FDO principles covered in chapter 3. Section 4.3 contributes a formal definition of RO-Crate using first order logic.
@graph.name: Chapter 4: RO-Crate

@graph.creditText: Simone Leo, et al. (2024): Recording provenance of workflow runs with RO-Crate. PLoS ONE 19(9):e0309210
@graph.name: Section 5.4: Recording provenance of workflow runs with RO-Crate
Recording provenance of workflow runs with RO-Crate (RO-Crate and mapping)

@graph.description: In order to investigate RQ3, and considering important parts of the FAIR principles are Reuse and provenance, this chapter examines in closer details how FAIR Digital Objects and RO-Crate can be used with Computational Workflows.      Section 5.1 proposes that tools in computational workflows, when wrapped as interoperable building blocks, can be considered as FAIR Digital Objects, with a use case from biomolecular simulation.            Sections 5.2 and 5.3 explore how FDOs and Research Objects can be constructed incrementally using computational workflows, with a use case from specimen digitization in natural history collections.      Section 5.4 presents a profile of RO-Crate to capture workflow execution provenance, with incremental granularity levels and six workflow engine implementations. Use cases include machine learning-aided tumour detection and compatibility with PROV approaches.
@graph.name: Chapter 5: Computational Workflows

@graph.description: RO-Crate of PhD thesis at the University of Amsterdam
@graph.name: FAIR Research Objects and Computational Workflows – A Linked Data Approach
PhD defence: FAIR Research Objects and Computational Workflows – A Linked Data Approach
@graph.description: Stian Soiland-Reyes will defend the dissertation 'FAIR Research Objects and Computational Workflows – A Linked Data Approach'. Supervisors are Prof. P.T. Groth and Prof. C.A. Goble.

@graph.name: prof. dr. ir. C.T.A.M. de Laat
